skill.name: Command Development
skill.description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a slash command", "add a command", "write a custom command", "define command arguments", "use command frontmatter", "organize commands", "create command with file references", "interactive command", "use AskUserQuestion in command", or needs guidance on slash command structure, YAML frontmatter fields, dynamic arguments, bash execution in commands, user interaction patterns, or command development best practices for Claude Code.

security_audit.summary: Official skill from a trusted source with minimal audit required. No security concerns observed during file scan.

content.value_statement: You need reliable command patterns and frontmatter rules. This skill provides clear guidance, examples, and templates for Claude Code commands.
actual_capabilities: Explains slash command file locations for project, user, and plugin scopes
Documents YAML frontmatter fields such as description, allowed-tools, model, argument-hint, and disable-model-invocation
Shows dynamic argument usage with $ARGUMENTS and positional variables
Covers file references with @path and bash execution with !`command`
Describes plugin command patterns including ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} and component integration
limitations: Does not execute commands or modify files automatically
Focuses on Claude Code slash command format, not other platforms
Requires users to supply project context and desired workflows
Examples may need adaptation for specific repositories

use_cases.title: Build personal commands
use_cases.description: Create reusable slash commands for common reviews, tests, and documentation tasks.

use_cases.title: Standardize workflows
use_cases.description: Define project commands with argument hints and tool limits for consistent team usage.

use_cases.title: Ship plugin commands
use_cases.description: Design plugin command patterns with templates, scripts, and validation steps.

prompt_templates.title: Basic command
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a simple /review command with no frontmatter. It should ask Claude to review code for bugs and security issues.

prompt_templates.title: Arguments first
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a /fix-issue command that accepts an issue number with $ARGUMENTS and explains the expected arguments.

prompt_templates.title: Frontmatter control
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a /status command with frontmatter using allowed-tools: Bash(git:*), and include a short description.

prompt_templates.title: Interactive plugin
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a plugin command that uses AskUserQuestion to gather deployment settings and then outlines next steps.

output_examples.input: Create a /review command with frontmatter and argument hints
output: Includes frontmatter with description and argument-hint
Explains expected input and result clearly

best_practices: Write commands as instructions to Claude, not user-facing messages
Use concise descriptions and argument-hint fields for discovery
Restrict allowed-tools to the minimum needed for the task
anti_patterns: Using wildcard tool access without a clear need
Writing commands as marketing text instead of directives
Relying on complex arguments when an interactive flow is better

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude Code only?
faq.answer: Yes. It focuses on Claude Code slash command format and behavior.

faq.question: What limits does it have?
faq.answer: It provides guidance and examples. It does not run commands or change files.

faq.question: Can it integrate with plugins and scripts?
faq.answer: Yes. It covers plugin command patterns and ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} usage.

faq.question: Does it handle sensitive data safely?
faq.answer: It advises on tool limits. You control data exposure and file access.

faq.question: What if my command does not work?
faq.answer: Check frontmatter fields, argument usage, and allowed-tools settings.

faq.question: How is it different from generic prompt help?
faq.answer: It targets Claude Code command files, frontmatter, and plugin workflows.
